Popular courtroom recording software was infected with a backdoor trojan malware program for months. Many courts and court cases likely impacted. I'm a little surprised this isn't getting more press.

https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2024/05/23/cve-2024-4978-backdoored-justice-av-solutions-viewer-software-used-in-apparent-supply-chain-attack

CVE-2024-4978.description: Justice AV Solutions Viewer Setup 8.3.7.250-1 contains a malicious binary when executed and is signed with an unexpected authenticode signature. A remote, privileged threat actor may exploit this vulnerability to execute of unauthorized PowerShell commands.

posts.content:
Horizon3: CVE-2024-23108: Fortinet FortiSIEM 2nd Order Command Injection Deep-Dive
Fortinet back at it again with another deep dive of Fortinet FortiSIEM. After providing the vulnerability analysis for CVE-2023-34992 (see parent toot above), he briefly explains how CVE-2024-23108 and CVE-2024-23109 are patch bypasses. As @wdormann points out, "The injection-causing semicolon is moved from one argument to another. 🤦‍♂️" Proof of concept is provided.

You've read about it in Bleeping Computer's news article. Check out the vulnerability disclosure timeline here to see Zach Hanley's side of the story about Fortinet's botched disclosure.

#CVE_2024_23108 #proofofconcept #vulnerability #Horizon3 #Fortinet

posts.content:
@wdormann I was there for this! someone noticed some perfect 10.0 CVSSv3 scoring vulnerabilities buried in a 4 month old security advisory without any changelog.

@serghei asked Fortinet PSIRT about them and they straight up lied about it: https://mastodon.social/@serghei/111889892600716875

Zach Hanley's response: https://twitter.com/hacks_zach/status/1755309941982646695

Lol not sure whats going on over there, but they're real were a bypass of the 2023 CVE it got added to

@BleepingComputer posted a subsequent update with the following statement: "After contacting Fortinet once again, we were told their previous statement was “misstated” and that the two new CVEs are variants of the original flaw."

"The PSIRT team followed its process to add two similar variants of the previous CVE (CVE-2023-34992), tracked as CVE-2024-23108 and CVE-2024-23109 to our public advisory FG-IR-23-130, which was published in October 2023. The two new CVEs share the exact same description and score as the initial one; in parallel we updated MITRE. A reminder pointing to the updated Advisory will be included for our customers on Tuesday when Fortinet publishes its monthly advisory." – Fortinet.”

posts.content:

#CVE_2024_23108 #Fortinet #FortiSIEM #vulnerability #CVE #proofofconcept

CVE-2024-23108.description: An improper neutralization of special elements used in an os command ('os command injection') in Fortinet FortiSIEM version 7.1.0 through 7.1.1 and 7.0.0 through 7.0.2 and 6.7.0 through 6.7.8 and 6.6.0 through 6.6.3 and 6.5.0 through 6.5.2 and 6.4.0 through 6.4.2 allows attacker to execute unauthorized code or commands via via crafted API requests.

posts.content:
Veeam has issued an “enhanced update” to address CVE-2024-29212, an RCE flaw in its Service Provider Console (VSPC).

Sounds like an incomplete first patch:

“Although our initial patch, issued on May 7th, effectively addressed the primary concern, a subsequent review identified an area for further improvement. To ensure comprehensive protection, we swiftly developed and released a refined patch that fully mitigates the issue.”

https://www.helpnetsecurity.com/2024/05/08/cve-2024-29212/

#Veeam #Backup #CVE #Cybersecurity

CVE-2024-29212.description: Due to an  unsafe de-serialization method used by the Veeam Service Provider Console(VSPC) server in communication between the management agent and its components, under certain conditions, it is possible to perform Remote Code Execution (RCE) on the VSPC server machine.

posts.content:
Sysdig: DDoS-as-a-Service: The Rebirth Botnet
Sysdig reports a DDoS-as-a-Service Mirai-based botnet using the domain rebirthltd[.]com to launch attacks. One of the vulnerabilities targeted is a Ruckus AP remote code execution/cross-site request forgery vulnerability CVE-2023-25717 (9.8 critical, disclosed 08 February 2023 by Ruckus, has proof of concept, added to CISA KEV Catalog on 12 May 2023).Sysdig describes motivations, attribution, campaigns, infection methods, and detection methods. IOC not really included.

#threatintel #ddos #botnet #CVE_2023_25717 #ruckus #mirai #rebirth #vulcan

CVE-2023-25717.description: Ruckus Wireless Admin through 10.4 allows Remote Code Execution via an unauthenticated HTTP GET Request, as demonstrated by a /forms/doLogin?login_username=admin&password=password$(curl substring.

Horizon3: CVE-2024-23108: Fortinet FortiSIEM 2nd Order Command Injection Deep-Dive
Fortinet back at it again with another deep dive of Fortinet FortiSIEM. After providing the vulnerability analysis for CVE-2023-34992 (see parent toot above), he briefly explains how CVE-2024-23108 and CVE-2024-23109 are patch bypasses. As @wdormann points out, "The injection-causing semicolon is moved from one argument to another. 🤦‍♂️" Proof of concept is provided.

You've read about it in Bleeping Computer's news article. Check out the vulnerability disclosure timeline here to see Zach Hanley's side of the story about Fortinet's botched disclosure.

#CVE_2024_23108 #proofofconcept #vulnerability #Horizon3 #Fortinet

account.note: This is not Simon. Opinions are made by a screaming goat and do not express the views or opinions of his goatherder. Timely and actionable goat information.

posts.content:
@wdormann I was there for this! someone noticed some perfect 10.0 CVSSv3 scoring vulnerabilities buried in a 4 month old security advisory without any changelog.

@serghei asked Fortinet PSIRT about them and they straight up lied about it: https://mastodon.social/@serghei/111889892600716875

Zach Hanley's response: https://twitter.com/hacks_zach/status/1755309941982646695

Lol not sure whats going on over there, but they're real were a bypass of the 2023 CVE it got added to

@BleepingComputer posted a subsequent update with the following statement: "After contacting Fortinet once again, we were told their previous statement was “misstated” and that the two new CVEs are variants of the original flaw."

"The PSIRT team followed its process to add two similar variants of the previous CVE (CVE-2023-34992), tracked as CVE-2024-23108 and CVE-2024-23109 to our public advisory FG-IR-23-130, which was published in October 2023. The two new CVEs share the exact same description and score as the initial one; in parallel we updated MITRE. A reminder pointing to the updated Advisory will be included for our customers on Tuesday when Fortinet publishes its monthly advisory." – Fortinet.”

CVE-2023-34992.description: A improper neutralization of special elements used in an os command ('os command injection') in Fortinet FortiSIEM version 7.0.0 and 6.7.0 through 6.7.5 and 6.6.0 through 6.6.3 and 6.5.0 through 6.5.1 and 6.4.0 through 6.4.2 allows attacker to execute unauthorized code or commands via crafted API requests.

posts.content: The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2024-5035, carries a CVSS score of 10.0. It impacts all versions of the router firmware including and prior to 1_1.1.6. It has been patched in version 1_1.1.7 released on May 24, 2024. https://thehackernews.com/2024/05/tp-link-gaming-router-vulnerability.html
